original_title: Sri Lanka tourism minister defends price floors on hotel rooms
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s tourism minister Harin Fernando defended interventions to charge above market prices from tourists as price floors are making a comeback in the island.
“There is a lot of arguments going on about minimum hotel rates,” Minister Fernando told a forum marking gains made over the past year.
“We do have to compete with certain countries that is true. But you can’t sustain by selling a five -star room at 50 US dollars a night. How would you expect to pay staff?”
Sri Lanka has in the recent past placed price ceilings on some consumer goods like eggs to give lower prices to domestic consumers.
Under pressure from nationalist businesses Sri Lanka has also placed import tariffs, ostensibly to inflict harm on foreigners, but actually hurting domestic consumers by higher than world prices.

Domestic consumers are trapped within a nationally sovereign region, where a coercive state can impose its will but it is less easy to inflict harm on foreigners who can choose between foreign goods or foreign destinations, analysts say.
Sri Lanka’s price ceiling and price floor come as President Ranil Wickremesinghe is trying to a create a competitive market economy. (Colombo/June27/2023)
